name: How Sustainable Can a Cocktail Bar Really Be?

text.text: How Sustainable Can a Cocktail Bar Really Be?

with Tom Soden from Nine Lives 

Take one step into Nine Lives and you’re a million miles from the hustle and crap of London Bridge. From dark wood features and palm fronds to a vintage sound system and layers of incense, every detail has been carefully planned to create that elusive feeling of escapism. Details that Tom, one of the founders, took 30 hours to painstakingly write into a manifesto (alright mate!).

He believes a good bar needs a purpose and his is clearly twofold, combining: 1) the experience, and 2) sustainability. We caught up with him over cocktails to discuss the difficulties of balancing the two.

It may seem like a load of hogwash from your seat on the Central Line, but travelling the world seeing things first hand made Tom realise the effect we’re having on the planet. Between water shortages in California and beaches covered in plastic (all over the world) Tom started to realise something had to be done. It was all that and becoming a father that pushed him to act.

In this infamous manifesto Tom detailed every aspect of the bar from the friend he convinced to become a doorman to the careful sustainability measures. He decked out the space with upcycled furniture, bamboo lampshades and a refurbished ice machine. 

'Why buy a new one when you can fix an existing one?' he asks.

Apart from the obvious cuts on plastic a lot of work has been put into using local ingredients and products with a low carbon footprint. Tom explains how most spirit brands are relatively sustainable anyway (glass bottles, old fashioned techniques, non perishable products which can be shipped by sea). And then there’s the garden.

In a small space out back they grow what they can, herbs and some fruit for the cocktail menu. What they lack in gardening skills St Mungo’s charity makes up for, caring for the plants and helping to rehabilitate homeless people all in one neat bundle. They can’t grow it all and a few crops have failed completely, but it’s a start. And learning about the value of growing things is priceless right?

In searching for options with a lower carbon footprint, these guys have swapped out limes for apples. Ok so they still use citrus in some of their drinks, but they've made their Kelross Daiquiri lime free by getting Bramley apples to bring the acidity. They’re locally sourced (points) and make for a crisp, smooth drinker that gets more flavourful with each sip (double points). It may not be quite the same drink, but the drinking experience doesn't suffer - it's still extremely tasty stuff.

Tom would be the first to admit that Nine Lives isn’t perfect. It’s a long way from being carbon neutral, that’s for sure, but he believes in starting a conversation that will lead to change in the long run. 

'It’s a marathon, not a sprint. If we can stop people using plastic straws maybe they’ll stop buying fruit or veg wrapped in plastic?'

It’s hard to measure the effect of their work at this stage though we can’t help but root for anyone who’s taking a step in - what is undeniably - the right direction.

tip.text:
Take one step into Nine Lives and you’re a million miles away from the hustle of London Bridge. From dark wood features and palm fronds to a vintage sound system and layers of incense, every detail has been carefully planned to create that elusive feeling of escapism. But that's not all this cocktail bar is up to. It's also making lots of noise on the sustainability train, with low waste cocktails, low plastic usage, up-cycled furniture and a herb garden out back (run by St Mungo's homeless charity no less).

And the results for your drinking pleasure? Sweet treats like the Kelross Daiquiri which replaces limes with relatively local Bramley apples; and the Kafé Kerna,l a non-alcoholic, bitter coffee number. If you've a more classical flavour palate, order the (off menu) Lutra which fills your mouth beautifully with Tanqueray, sake, dry white wine, lemon, sugar and creme de peche. At £9.50 you'd be hard pressed to find better in these ends.
